Let him be himself at his own pace dude. Just be there for him no matter what. You trying to force him into something is not what he wants or needs.

Take your time and discover yourself. Go slow and start thinking about going on dates with a guy, think about holding his hand, eating a bowl of popcorn at the movies together, think about running your hands through his hair. Build it in your mind and you'll get to know yourself more, don't be afraid if some of your thoughts feel wrong. Just go wherever they lead, remember that only you know what's going on in your head. Good luck discovering yourself:)

Then the best advice I have for you is that you write him a letter that explains what your issues are, tell him he needs to read the entire letter before responding. Include how you feel about him in the letter and explain that you want a healthy dialogue, include what your idea of that is. After you write the letter you should sleep on it and read it again the next day. If you still agree with it then give it to him. Hopefully he'll see the effort that went into this. Good luck :)

I grew up in a conservative town with a ton of conservative people around. When I was younger I always heard people saying that being gay was a choice and that made sense to me, I'm bi. I thought everyone was attracted to both and you just chose one and went with it. After a few years i never really thought about it, that's just who I was, I was a straight guy.
I dated plenty of women and never had any problems but at sixteen I joined weights class and we all showered together everyday after class. I couldn't stop thinking about the guys but I convinced myself that it was what every normal straight guy did. I had a girlfriend after all and she was about to be prom queen. I pushed it from my mind but sometimes when I went to relieve myself I'd think about the guys in the showers. I'd feel disgusted afterwards and this went on till I was 18. I started watching gay porn in college and first started flirting with the idea of being bi around 19. I got into a relationship at 20 with a girl and I once again pushed those thoughts aside. I didn't really embrace being bi until I was 21/22 then I came out at 23. I fucked my first guy at 23, a guy I met off tinder who is an actual millionaire...that was a weird time. I dated a girl for a bit after that and then I met my now ex. He is gorgeous and was some great sex big what really struck me was how easy the relationship was. It didn't last long but it felt very right.
Today I still sleep with both men and women but I'm only looking for a relationship with a man. I've gone on a lot of dates recently and find that it's a decent bit harder dating men than women but there is a guy I'm talking to now that seems promising, have our first date Saturday, wish us luck....also thanks for sticking in this long lol
If he brings it up just say something like "it's not my fault you're hot and I'm horny" just laugh it off

That hobby you had a decade or two ago, start doing it again (for me it was painting).
Distract yourself on improving yourself. Make that level of joy you had with him your new regular. It's gonna hurt for a while, you'll be better for it.

You have some great heights and deep lows ahead of you. You'll look back to this time for the rest of your life, nostalgia will build up your mountains and smooth over your valleys.
Squeeze as much joy from this moment as you can, be yourself and be ready to discover things you didn't know about yourself. Have fun and be safe.

I woke up yesterday over my ex. It feels great and I can finally be all in on dates again.
I have a first date tomorrow at my favorite restaurant with a guy I've been texting all week. Wish me luck :)

I, you and everyone else tends to let their first get any with anything. It's the first time we really felt this way, this person is the best by default and who doesn't want the story book life of settling down with their first love. We hear that everyone will be cheated on at some point in their lives, that some of our partners will be rude or cruel to us. Going into these relationships we know all the warning signs and we know, we KNOW, that we would never fall into the trap of a bad relationship. We think our relationship just has a few problems but it's my first so I probably did something wrong.
No. You did nothing wrong. He is not the man you are meant to be with. If you forgive him he will betray you again. You need to get out. It will hurt. You will be better for it.
After you leave, take some time and focus on you, you'll miss the relationship, but force your way through it and when you're ready try again. Don't go back to the first guy.
You'll date people who buy you flowers for no reason. you'll find guys who build up a date for days, telling you it'll be the best date ever, you love every moment, a night to always remember, then when date night comes it's just a table set up in the middle of his apartment with a lit candle in the center and McDonald's on the counter, when you ask him what this is he'll say "I just wanted to stare at you in candle light for a while".
There are great things out there for you. Go out there and find them.
Good luck :)
Sometimes the next year, sometimes the next day. I do it when I'm ready.
